verses.text: For behold, in those days and at that time, when I restore the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem,
verses.comment: God announces a future restoration for His people, referencing the return from exile but also suggesting a greater fulfillment.

verses.text: I will gather all the nations and bring them down to the Valley of Jehoshaphat. And I will enter into judgment with them there over My people and My heritage Israel, whom they have scattered among the nations, and they have divided up My land.
verses.comment: The 'Valley of Jehoshaphat' is likely symbolic, meaning 'Yahweh judges.' This is a prophecy of a future universal judgment, often interpreted both literally and as foreshadowing final judgment.

verses.text: They have cast lots for My people, and given a boy for a prostitute, and sold a girl for wine, and have drunk it.
verses.comment: This gruesome image underscores the depths of sin and injustice, pointing later to the need for redemption that Christ provides.

verses.text: What are you to Me, O Tyre and Sidon, and all the regions of Philistia? Are you repaying Me for something? If you are paying Me back, I will swiftly and speedily return your recompense on your own head.
verses.comment: God addresses the surrounding pagan nations, highlighting that human attempts to retaliate against God are futile.

verses.text: For you have taken My silver and My gold, and have carried My precious treasures into your temples.
verses.comment: The taking of sacred objects indicates profanation of what is holy. This ties into Christian teaching on proper reverence for things set apart for God.

verses.text: You have sold the people of Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks, to remove them far from their own border.
verses.comment: This verse references historical slave trade but also points to deeper themes of exile and restoration.

verses.text: Look, I will stir them up from the place where you have sold them, and I will return your recompense on your own head.
verses.comment: God's justice requires restoration and retribution, which foreshadows God's ultimate plan of justice in salvation history.

verses.text: I will sell your sons and your daughters into the hand of the people of Judah, and they will sell them to the Sabeans, to a nation far away— for the LORD has spoken.
verses.comment: This is a reversal of fortune—an instance of poetic justice. The text underscores the seriousness of covenant violations.

verses.text: Proclaim this among the nations: Prepare for war! Stir up the mighty men. Let all the warriors draw near, let them come up.
verses.comment: This call signals a universal judgment, often connected with eschatological images found in Revelation.

verses.text: Beat your plowshares into swords, and your pruning hooks into spears; let the weak say, 'I am strong.'
verses.comment: This is a reversal of Isaiah 2:4, where swords become plowshares. Here, even the weak are to prepare for God's judgment.

verses.text: Hasten and come, all you surrounding nations, and gather yourselves there. Bring down, O LORD, Your mighty ones.
verses.comment: The gathering of the nations for judgment symbolizes the universality of God's reign.

verses.text: Let the nations stir themselves up and come up to the Valley of Jehoshaphat; for there I will sit to judge all the surrounding nations.
verses.comment: God as universal judge appears here—anticipating the Messiah's role as ultimate judge (see Matthew 25:31–32).

verses.text: Put in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe. Go in, tread, for the winepress is full. The vats overflow, for their wickedness is great.
verses.comment: The imagery of harvest and winepress is used for judgment, echoed in Revelation concerning the final judgment.

verses.text: Multitudes, multitudes, in the valley of decision! For the day of the LORD is near in the valley of decision.
verses.comment: The 'valley of decision' signifies a decisive moment in God's plan and reflects the urgency of repentance.

verses.text: The sun and the moon grow dark, and the stars withdraw their shining.
verses.comment: Cosmic signs accompany God's intervention in history—a motif echoed in the apocalyptic discourse of Jesus.

verses.text: The LORD will roar from Zion, and utter His voice from Jerusalem, and the heavens and the earth will shake. But the LORD will be a refuge for His people, a stronghold for the people of Israel.
verses.comment: God's special protection for His people is highlighted. This is a foreshadowing of the ongoing spiritual refuge provided in the Church.

verses.text: So you shall know that I am the LORD your God, who dwells in Zion, My holy mountain. And Jerusalem will be holy, and strangers shall never again pass through it.
verses.comment: The holiness of the city reflects the call to be a distinct, set apart people—fulfilled ultimately in the new Jerusalem.

verses.text: And on that day the mountains shall drip sweet wine, the hills shall flow with milk, and all the streams of Judah shall flow with water. And a fountain shall come forth from the house of the LORD and water the Valley of Shittim.
verses.comment: Abundance and blessing flow from the worship of God. The fountain image is echoed by Jesus (John 7:37–39), who speaks of living water coming from the heart of the believer.

verses.text: Egypt shall become a desolation and Edom a desolate wilderness, for the violence done to the people of Judah, because they have shed innocent blood in their land.
verses.comment: Judgment on the enemies of God's people shows God's role as righteous judge who vindicates His own.

verses.text: But Judah shall be inhabited forever, and Jerusalem to all generations.
verses.comment: This speaks to the eternal security of God's people—a promise fulfilled spiritually in Christ’s everlasting kingdom (Luke 1:33).

verses.text: I will avenge their blood, blood I have not yet avenged, for the LORD dwells in Zion.
verses.comment: God's presence with His people and His final justice are foundational truths, fulfilled ultimately in Christ, and expressed in the unity and endurance of God’s people throughout the ages.
